video.title: Android Studio Tutorial - Build a GPS App
video.description:
Learn how to create a GPS Android App. You will learn how to use FusedLocationProviderClient, Google Play services, Location Provider, and other parts of a GPS-aware application.

💻 Starting XML file: https://github.com/shadsluiter/gpsDemoStarting/blob/master/activity_main.xml

✏️ Course developed by Shad Sluiter. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/shadsluiter

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

replies.author: Kornél Horváth
replies.text: @Tommytoe135 thanks for the solution, it helped me with error "Error invoke virtual method 'double android.location.Location.getLatitude()' on a null object reference", now everythings working fine for me :)

replies.author: Tommytoe135
replies.text:
Instead of doing the 'locationRequest = new LocationRequest();', which is indeed marked as deprecated,
you could use the following:

locationRequest = LocationRequest.create()
           .setInterval(1000 * 30)
           .setFastestInterval(1000 * 5)
           .setPriority(LocationRequest.PRIORITY_BALANCED_POWER_ACCURACY)

topLevelComment.author: Eric Man
topLevelComment.text: java.lang.NullPointerException: Attempt to invoke interface method 'int java.util.List.size()' on a null object reference

replies.author: marky j
replies.text: @the guy with no name I was getting a similar issue (not sure exactly the conditions of the original asker). The issue I had was trying to add and size the list. I'm really not sure how his code was working, but coming from a C# background, when you use lists you usually need to initialize them first. So where I declared "List<Location> savedLocations" in the MainActivity file, I changed this to "List<Location> savedLocations = new ArrayList<>();". This simply declares the variable as an empty list, this concept is used in C# also, hence why I noticed it. I'm very new to Java and Android, but most languages tend to share common traits such as this. Hope this helps you and anyone else in the future.
